fields.description:
We should not verify the signature in bundle manifests as we may not have the necessary key.

{quote}
 -k, --privatekey path
	
The path to a PEM-encoded RSA key file. You'll need to specify this key to unbundle this bundle, so keep it in a safe place. Note that the key doesn't have to be registered to your AWS account.

Required: Yes

Example: -k pk-HKZYKTAIG2ECMXYIBH3HXV4ZBEXAMPLE.pem
{quote}

http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/CommandLineReference/CLTRG-ami-bundle-image.html

Presumably the signature can only be validated by the end-user when they are unbundling.
fields.summary: EC2 bundle manifest signatures should not be validated by service

comments.body: If we make this change we should revert and close TOOLS-550.
[~viglesias] will check on AWS and may pass to [~sjones].

When I tested this shortly before this bug's filing EC2 was perfectly happy to allow one to register a bundle with a corrupt signature.  That seemed to be good enough for [~viglesias] when I spoke with him about it.

Given:
{quote}
--skipmanifest
Does not upload the manifest.
Required: No
{quote}
for [ec2-upload-bundle|http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/CommandLineReference/CLTRG-ami-upload-bundle.html], does that mean that EC2 ignores the manifest completely?

No, it still uses the manifest to find the bundle's parts and presumably for checksum verification.  It just seems to ignore the signature.

\-\-skipmanifest just provides a means of uploading the parts separately, though I'm not really sure when that would be useful.
You can verify by bundling/uploading/registering an image using certificate credentials from another cloud.
